bibl.title: Letter from Jefferson Randolph Kean to Mrs. Mason Young, January 3, 1901

div1.p: Kean describes the round of New Year's parties, his children, and studying for his promotional exam. Kean also details the success of the mosquito experiments and the army's efforts to eliminate mosquitoes.

div1.head: Letter from Jefferson Randolph Kean to Mrs. Mason Young, January 3, 1901

opener.dateline:
HEADQUARTERS
DEPARTMENT OF CUBA
Office of the Chief Surgeon
HAVANA
Jan. 3rd 1901

div1.p:
A Happy New Year to
you dearest Gran and
to all the House of Young.
It has opened very well
for all of us, with bright-
warm weather and all
well and happy.

“Our board is little but our
hearts are great.”

So are our appetites -
We all went to Playa for
a swim in the afternoon
of New Years Day, and
in the evening went to
see the Foye-Homebarracks
wedding at Gen. Lee's old
Hdqtrs. There was an enor-
mous crush and all the
military hierarchy turned
out to see the fun, but it
is said not much of the
jeute fina of Havana.
The bride is handsome
and fat and will look
fair fat & forty in three
years from now altho she
is only twenty two --

You could have cut the
garlic with a knife, Helen
would have enjoyed it im-
mensely- There has been
much giving on lately in
the way of dances, card
parties, etc. I have not
been able to do any studying
at all altho, the order for my examination
may come any day. So with the 1st I
I wore off from all drinks, card parties
& pleasures of all sorts that would interfere
with work, and will ride on the water-
wagon until I stand my exam-
It seems pretty certain now that the Army
bill will pass, and that promotes me
& half a dozen below me. So you will
plainly see that it behooves me to buckle
down and learn the morphological and
cultural peculiarities of the one hundred
and forty seven species of pathological
bacteria. I suppose you keep posted
on the mosquito question. I no longer call
it a theory as it has passed into the
domain of well established facts- All five
of the mosquito-bitten men came down &
not a man from the infected clothing
house, altho- for a month we have had
non-immunes sleeping in the beds and
wearing the pajamas of yellow fever
patients, & have tried in every way except
the mosquito, to infect them. It is a great discovery.
HEADQUARTERS
DEPARTMENT OF CUBA
Office of the Chief Surgeon
HAVANA
Gen Wood has on my recom-
mendation published a
mosquito order for the
troops, & Gorgas will make
waging war against them
a prominent feature of
his sanitary work here-
after.

Well you are probably
more interested in that
Beautiful Bobby than
in Culex faciatus, So I
must say a word about
him. He is getting to be
a fine big baby and is
as good as gold and
a general favorite.
He is said by people who
have every reason to be
unprejudiced impartial
and truthful to be a
very handsome - baby.
As I jump him I stand
high in his good graces &
he grins and puts out
his arms to me whenever
I come around.

Martha is much more
serene and well behaved
I think than she was
at Morristown. She has
now settled down to the
role of a little bare head-
ed tom-boy & talks of nothing
but looses & mules, & the
points of her horse Feather.

Louise is very well and very pretty.
She had a dressmaker in Morristown who
has sent her a bill, but as said bill
(enclosed) does not state the lady's
initials or address I am at a loss how
to pay her unless you will be good enough
to do so. As L. says that the dresses
didn't fit she dont seem to care whether
the said Mrs Fox is paid or not-
L. tells me too that she owes you $1700
so I enclose a N. Y. draft for $4500
If you will pay Mrs Fox & square your
ape with the balance I will be very
grateful to you.

Goodbye dear Gran I must get
back to the bacteria. With kisses
for the girls I remain with much love
div1.closer:
Your son Randolph I sent Mr. Y. a few Partegas- did
they arrive safety?
